varPro for unsupervised problems

Min Lu (luminwin@gmail.com)

Lili Zhou (lxz516@miami.edu)

Aster Shear (aster.shear@gmail.com)

Udaya B. Kogalur (ubk@kogalur.com)

Hemant Ishwaran (hemant.ishwaran@gmail.com)

2025-05-14

Introduction

VarPro performs variable selection in an unsupervised setting by analyzing the structure of random forests built without outcome labels. The core idea is to assess variable importance by tracing how features influence tree splits—without relying on a response variable. Different forest construction strategies can be selected using the method option:

  • method = "auto" (default): Constructs a random forest autoencoder by regressing selected variables against themselves. This is a specialized form of multivariate forest that learns data structure directly from the variables. While effective for structure discovery, it may be slower on large datasets.

  • method = "unsupv": Builds a forest using standard unsupervised random forest techniques that do not rely on any outcome. This method is faster and more scalable, making it well-suited for high-dimensional problems.

  • method = "rnd": Uses forests constructed with pure random splitting, entirely independent of data-driven criteria. This approach sacrifices structure for speed, making it ideal for extremely large datasets.

VarPro computes importance scores using an entropy-based criterion defined in terms of overall feature variance. Users can supply their own entropy functions to define custom importance measures. See the examples below.

A quick start 

library(varPro)
data(BostonHousing, package = "mlbench")

## default call
o <- unsupv(BostonHousing)
print(importance(o))

             mean       std         z
nox     0.5880322 0.3838791 1.5318162

## unsupervised splitting 
o <- unsupv(BostonHousing, method = "unsupv")
print(importance(o))

Example with Factors 

## load the data
data(BostonHousing, package = "mlbench")

## convert some of the features to factors
Boston <- BostonHousing
Boston$zn <- factor(Boston$zn)
Boston$chas <- factor(Boston$chas)
Boston$lstat <- factor(round(0.2 * Boston$lstat))
Boston$nox <- factor(round(20 * Boston$nox))
Boston$rm <- factor(round(Boston$rm))

## call unsupervised varpro and print importance
print(importance(o <- unsupv(Boston)))

Custom Importance Functions – Option 1: Inline Entropy

VarPro allows users to define a custom importance function through the (hidden) entropy argument. This function is evaluated internally during forest construction.

The custom function must return a list with two elements: 1. A scalar importance value. 2. An entropy list containing the comp and oob membership vectors.

Example:

my.entropy <- function(xC, xO, ...) {
  wss <- mean(apply(rbind(xO, xC), 2, sd, na.rm = TRUE))
  bss <- mean(apply(xO, 2, sd, na.rm = TRUE)) +
         mean(apply(xC, 2, sd, na.rm = TRUE))
  imp <- 0.5 * bss / wss

  entropy <- list(comp = list(...)$compMembership,
                  oob  = list(...)$oobMembership)

  list(imp = imp, entropy)
}

o <- unsupv(BostonHousing, entropy = my.entropy)
print(importance(o))

             mean       std         z
nox     0.5689125 0.3900506 1.4585608
indus   0.5087139 0.3900071 1.3043709
rad     0.3504640 0.3520091 0.9956106
zn      0.3997953 0.4147441 0.9639565
medv    0.4126304 0.4310544 0.9572582
tax     0.3490256 0.3727909 0.9362502
crim    0.3446691 0.3990397 0.8637464
dis     0.2564835 0.3807887 0.6735587
ptratio 0.2151499 0.3324902 0.6470863
lstat   0.2429619 0.3907914 0.6217177
age     0.2182291 0.3743837 0.5829022
rm      0.1556733 0.3331967 0.4672112
b       0.0000000 0.0000000       NaN
chas    0.0000000 0.0000000       NaN

Custom Importance Functions – Option 2: Post-hoc Construction

As an alternative, users can compute variable importance after model fitting by working directly with the $entropy output. This approach gives full control over the definition of importance scores.

o <- unsupv(BostonHousing, ntree = 3, max.rules.tree = 10)
library(magrittr)
imp <- do.call(rbind, lapply(seq_along(o$entropy), function(j) {
  rules <- o$entropy[[j]]
  rO <- do.call(rbind, lapply(rules, function(r) {
    xC <- o$x[r[[1]], ]
    xO <- o$x[r[[2]], ]
    y <- factor(c(rep(0, nrow(xC)), rep(1, nrow(xO))))
    xnm <- names(o$entropy)[j]
    x <- rbind(xC, xO)
    x <- x[, colnames(x) != xnm]
    
    fit <- tryCatch(
      suppressWarnings(glmnet::cv.glmnet(as.matrix(x), y, family = "binomial")),
      error = function(e) NULL
    )
    if (!is.null(fit)) {
      beta <- setNames(rep(0, ncol(x)), colnames(x))
      vec <- coef(fit, s = fit$lambda.min)[-1, 1]
      beta[names(vec)] <- vec
      beta
    } else {
      NULL
    }
  }))
  if (!is.null(rO)) {
    val <- colMeans(rO, na.rm = TRUE)
    names(val) <- colnames(rO)
    return(val)
  } else {
    return(NULL)
  }
}) |> setNames(names(o$entropy)))

print(imp)

               zn        indus           nox          rm           age           dis
crim   0.00000000  0.000000000 -1.804789e+00  0.00000000  0.000000e+00  0.0000000000
zn     0.00000000 -0.054268954  4.243649e+00  0.00000000  6.905852e-03 -0.0050155399
indus  0.00000000  0.000000000  6.217249e-15  0.00000000 -1.387779e-16  0.0000000000
nox   -0.45188489 -0.007111930 -3.445737e-02  0.01632731 -1.242414e-02 -0.0261679775
age   -0.84147835 -0.008322689 -4.419269e-02 -1.48451375  6.310935e-02 -0.0221405101

lstat -1.665748e-01
medv   0.000000e+00

In the above examples, the iith row serves as a ensembled regression model, representing the importance scores for the iith variable.

Summary
Both approaches offer flexibility in defining importance scores tailored to domain-specific objectives. Option 1 is more integrated, while Option 2 offers full post-processing control.

ClusterPro for Unsupervised Data Visualization

VarPro includes a powerful tool for unsupervised data visualization.

For each VarPro rule, a two-class analysis is performed by comparing the rule-defined region to its complementary region. This analysis produces regression coefficients that highlight variables most associated with the release variable.

These coefficients are then used to scale the centroids of the two regions. By saving all such pairs of scaled centroids, VarPro constructs an enhanced learning dataset specific to the release variable.

You can then apply standard visualization tools (e.g., PCA, t-SNE, UMAP) to this enhanced dataset to explore complex relationships and structures in the data.

Example of 4-cluster simulation 

if (library("MASS", logical.return=TRUE)) {


fourcsim <- function(n=500, sigma=2) {
  
  cl1 <- mvrnorm(n,c(0,4),cbind(c(1,0),c(0,sigma)))
  cl2 <- mvrnorm(n,c(4,0),cbind(c(1,0),c(0,sigma)))
  cl3 <- mvrnorm(n,c(0,-4),cbind(c(1,0),c(0,sigma)))
  cl4 <- mvrnorm(n,c(-4,0),cbind(c(1,0),c(0,sigma)))
  dta <- data.frame(rbind(cl1,cl2,cl3,cl4))
  colnames(dta) <- c("x","y")
  data.frame(dta, noise=matrix(rnorm((n*4)*20),ncol=20))

}

d4c <- fourcsim()
o4c <- clusterpro(d4c)
par(mfrow=c(2,2));plot(o4c,1:4)

}

Example of real data 

data(Glass, package = "mlbench")
dg <- Glass

## with class label
og <- clusterpro(dg)
par(mfrow=c(3,3));plot(og,1:16)

## without class label
dgU <- Glass; dgU$Type <- NULL
ogU <- clusterpro(dgU)
par(mfrow=c(3,3));plot(ogU,1:9)

For large datasets, consider using parallel::mclapply to improve computation time.
